and i bounced around from job to job for a little while in full-time development as a lot of people in my industry
especially in australia do um but eventually kind of four years in i went and landed a job at a consultancy
this consultancy is ssw you may have heard of them they have speakers at ndc all the time
and that was fantastic i really really enjoyed my time with them and the thing that it made me
kind of realize is there's a big difference between um being a full-time developer for a
software company and being a software consultant um the pressures are different the the
industries are different and one of the things i realized that it's it's actually a really good idea this is
the first tip of the talk it's a really good idea to give consulting a try because
you get you learn a few skills that i think are really important when it comes to trying and building a separate company or product and a few
of those benefits uh you learn to sell yourself so with consulting you're the product and
you need to convince people that they should be paying for your product that they should be paying for your software consulting
abilities and so you do have to you know work with clients and customers to you know prove your worth
you also need to manage relationships so whereas when i was a full-time developer you kind of only really interacted with
your colleagues maybe your bosses and some other departments but when you're a consultant you're
working directly with the customers so you're taking on that feedback you're working with them to develop what it is
you're doing and you need to manage those relationships good and bad and part of that is being taught
responsibility and accountability because when a a bug occurs and if it's a bad bug
especially but when the customer is angry when you're a full-time dev a lot of the time the
customer will be calling customer support they'll take care of it they'll log a bug comes into your ticket queue you can fix it and get it out the
door whereas in consulting the angry customer knocks on your door and says hey why is this broken
and you need to then a manage that relationship and b take accountability because if it's a bad bug what are you going to do to fix that and
make amends for that kind of thing and finally it really trains you to think about business needs over
development needs so the um
again as a full-time developer i was kind of always thinking about i really i want to make really good software because i'm good at what i do i want to
make sure that it's it's good features it's polished it looks nice it's stable it's tested
um whereas in consulting world you need to balance that with what the customer wants
right so if they if you want to build them a really nice administration screen but they don't really need that they're
happy just to call you and get you to change a database field now and then then you you can't really just go ahead
and do what you want anyway you've got to balance what the business needs and the value they're paying for
versus what you know you would traditionally want to do as a developer and so what i realized is that this
actually boils down into sales communication and business three really important skill sets i
think you need when you go to create your own company or product and that just kind of magically came out of
consulting so that's why my first tip is you know consider going into consulting at least just for a little
bit give it a try um but i mean as always i like to jump around
in my um in my career and at the time came where i got the itch
you know i got the i got the side project itch where i wanted to start a new thing

this was after having done consulting for a little while and my now business partner and i uh who

but it was a bit of a tangent a very small small thing and as we were talking to angel investor
i kind of i thought i remembered back to to those days where i was like oh gee i'd really like to do that

our business plans and market analysis and now we just built it [Laughter]
we didn't bother with any of that stuff we just got in and built the thing um and so this is
you know uh during kind of towards the end of my consulting career and my
my business partner was um freelancing at the time and we just went and started
building it but the the thing with hindsight is um it's at this point that we should
have stopped and this is where i want to kind of give out some advice it's here's what i should have done at that exact point
instead of building it and it's it's sitting there and it's thinking how do i land on an idea what do i choose what do i need to
know to start a startup to start a product a service a company anything like that
and so the first thing i think i would do now if i was doing it again is to think about the business model the
business model is one of the more important things about you know the company and can tell you a lot about how it's going to work now the
most i'll just give you a few examples but the most popular one here is obviously subscription asset access most sas companies are
subscription based you pay 50 a month you get access to the software but there's a bunch you probably
haven't thought of as well um obviously there's just one off payments uh think about an e-book think about a
mobile app where you pay once and you get access to that software and that's it they can be
lucrative uh business ventures as well and they can be good ones to start off with if you're just looking to bring some revenue in the door
my favorite example is a mate of mine from ssw who was a dietitian before he became a
software developer had a whole bunch of cobbled together software where you filled in a google form and it sent it to
some a pdf generator it sent basically a diet sheet off to the customer and that
was all cobbled together using no custom software just all connected together and that was a very viable
business uh he did pretty well from that and so you don't always have to go straight into sas
you can also do other things um you can sell data and i'm not talking about the evil facebook selling their soul kind of data um you
can just uh make the collection of data very easy and then sell the insights and results of that data onto
your customers as well and i have an example where a high performance fitness company
give out very high highly accurate hardware that's expensive they give that out for free to collect
the data and then they will charge the company only on the insights of that data and that's just one way to go about
things and then you've got pay as you go now this is what we ended up landing on
um and the classic example of a pay-as-you-go company are things like azure or aws right where the
um you you know you only pay for what you use and the problem with this kind of business model and this should have been
a red flag when we started is that it only works when you've got an economy of scale
right so you have to have loads of computing equipment to be able to give out tiny pieces to everyone so that they
only have to pay a little bit each you need loads of customers for that to work well and that's one of the things
we ran into as well our business model as a payments gateway is to take a cut of the transaction fee now if
we only get a very very small fraction of that we need loads of customers to make this work
and you need loads of volume to drive down your supplier cost so it's a bit of a chicken and egg
scenario there where you need volume to get cheaper prices but you need cheaper prices to get volume and so that would have been red flag
number one second thing i want you to look about look at is the industry that you're
thinking about getting into because another thing i didn't think about is that this you're going to be in this industry for
the long term so if you don't enjoy the industry that you're thinking about building a product or service for
you're not going to have a very good time now luckily i really love payments so i've got at least that one ticked off
but the the second thing here is that you you should probably have good access to this industry as well
uh and for example if i was going to if i was thinking about i don't know a piece of software that helped movie stars find new homes
if i can't get access to the movie stars to try and sell them my product then i'm not going to have a very good
time either and so if you have access but if i was like a script writer or a cameraman or someone who had just
slightly more access to me they might be more successful and so if you have a passion and access
fantastic but that's something important to think about and thirdly think about your competition
as well now the key reason i suggest that you should think about your competition is because
it can have already validated the business model and i think that's probably the most important one here and it's where our
sky collect that initial go at trying to do some stuff there didn't work because there wasn't very
many other competitors that did what we did um and no one really charged the same way
so no one was used to paying for this service so trying to sell something that no one's
kind of already paying for or doesn't know anyone that's paying for is a really difficult challenge whereas
if you pick a business model that exists already and this is something we thankfully did right um there's tons of
payment gateways we just picked the same one put our rates slightly higher because we had to but also we added a
bunch of value and that's how we handled the second point here can you differentiate yourself
um you know if you've got competition you need to be able to say why people should choose you
and not just go with the existing competition um and for us it was a bunch of accounting value-add stuff
um but not super important the the fact is that we we looked at
businesses that existed already and hint we actually looked at a uk business that wasn't yet in australia
and we copied their business model so that's a neat little trick we did um but then the
the third thing you need to think about when you're kind of talking about competitors is uh do you have sufficient resources to
compete or to achieve the business that you want to do and the way i like to think about
this and bear with me with the terrible metaphor here but the way i like to think about this is a civilization map i'm team red down
the bottom right hand there and up in the top left corner here is uh this really really
rich seam of ore in that mountain and i know how to mine ore and i know how to sell ore i just need to get there
and my little red army he can't compete with all those armies in the middle there
so instead what i should be doing is hanging out down here with the elves making some pixie dust and selling that that's kind of what i
have the resources and capability of achieving now there's a big caveat to this because
i think it's what we've also done and that's that whilst we're not we don't have the resources to just go
straight there we don't have millions of dollars in marketing and abilities to just go straight to this huge new market but what we can do is we
can kind of just skirt around the side and very very slowly take our time to get there and that's kind of what we're doing um
we're a very slow and steady growth business um we're chasing a big difficult to achieve business model um
but we are getting there and so i think um you know it's not a hard and fast rule that if you can't get there

but what it did do and this is kind of my accident is i built up a skill set around a product that was in demand in terms of
consulting there are lots of other businesses that need this kind of thing and so by the time that
my wife and i moved back to australia where the cost of living is suddenly back up high again we can't just survive on one salary what
i did is i went to the first user group that existed in newcastle which is where

user group talk list so i gave my talk um and during that talk i took that identity server
and i said hey by the way this is a specialty i have now um if anyone has any consulting work

into the just do it category of um advice here you know nike got it

do that one day or i'd love to go out and um you know move somewhere crazy or something like that but if you just do
it um you know you'll be surprised about what uh what happens to you um and i have a
great example which i'll just talk about really quickly because you might you might be wondering ben hey you're on a payments company how
does that actually work like how do you move money from a to b um and in australia there's this thing
called direct entry whereby i now have the ability to reach into any bank account in australia
and pluck out as much money as i want and transfer it to myself now i know that facility existed thanks
to the payments company i worked for at the beginning because they had that facility and so i
thought okay pinch we're going to be a payments company this is how we're going to start it is with this
plucking of the money facility but i don't know how to get that i guess i'll go to the bank so what i did is i
walked to uh one of the biggest banks in australia i walked into the city and i went to that big
corporate high-rise building i took the elevator to the 21st floor and i went to reception i said hey i'd
like this facility please and they go do you have an appointment yeah they promptly sent me downstairs to
the lobby uh to the branch and this was like walking into the dnb bank or something like that
and demanding an important corporate facility but no they sent me to the branch but what happened in that branch is i went
to a teller just one of the service people i said hey i want this facility they're like i don't know what you're talking about
here's my manager manager comes in i don't know what you're talking about but let me see if i can find someone
they get me from they get me a video call with someone slightly upstairs that person says oh i think i know that
let me find someone higher up that knows get me on a video call with them that person says yes i've heard of that facility let me find some
forms a couple weeks later i just get some forms fill them out send them back and i'm pretty sure that they weren't

that whole like just go do it just ask what you want um and and see what happens because you'll be surprised
i got back up invited to the top floors and and finally got to talk to people

love this strategy is the stair-step approach to um i guess self-financial
worth or whatever it is like self-sustaining um being self-sustained financially this is
a an approach that i found from rob welling who is the uh founder of the startups for the rest
of us podcast if you haven't been listening to that 100 just go and listen to

funded businesses so it's all the small guys lots of practical advice so many episodes uh really really
fantastic but the gist of that stair-step approach is that you start with easier to achieve
successful kind of businesses excuse me and so the first one for example here is
you could start with a one-time sale product so maybe write a wordpress plugin and just let
that tick over some money you know learn how to market that product learn how to sell that product um and then you you do that a few more
times second step is get a couple more of these um products under your belt and then
eventually the idea is you build up enough revenue to buy your time back and at that point once you've bought
your time back you can go start investing your time in building a recurring revenue product
and i feel like this would probably be the way i had done it um if i was doing it again now because
i've worked for free for too long and i think if i had had at least some other sources of revenue coming in that weren't trading my time for uh money

i've been lucky enough to kind of stumble my way towards somewhat success i've got fingers

what we did anyway um as developers we just went and built the thing that we wanted to build before

stripe like dream payments api but then it's also an accounting integration right it talks to invoicing
systems now we actually just built pinch the payments api engine first and that was
just going to be the product and because we're developers once we had built that we went uh how do we sell
this thing uh how do we test it you know what let's just build another thing that tests the first thing and so we
built this accounting integration now the problem was that we then had to
sell this thing so how did we how do we get that accounting integration into people's hands well here's a legitimate really useful
tip i think that people should pick up on um is instead of sending cold emails or cold
phone calls or something like that trying to sell this product what we did is we actually
sent out surveys there were still cold emails for the most part but we sent out surveys
to in our case accountants and bookkeepers because that's the industry we wanted to get into with our accounting integration
and we just asked their opinion so we said hey we're thinking about building a piece of
software that does this that was a lie we had already built it um you know on a scale of one to five how
does this feature you know how good would this feature be or how important is this feature to you what about this feature what about this
feature do you have any problems with getting paid right now and we just asked people's opinions on
uh what was effectively an industry problem and we got so many more responses back from that
survey than we did from any sales stuff we had done before and the important thing here
is that we actually caught the attention of someone who a wanted to be a customer but b was in
the business of kind of recommending apps and so he got us most of our initial
customer base because his job was to recommend different payment systems he you know basically sold our company for
us to a bunch of his colleagues and a bunch of his customers and that's kind of how we built up the the confidence there
and it was at this point when people started paying and paying and paying for the accounting integration
and my you piece of software behind the scenes you know amazing immaculate well
designed wasn't really being used but the accounting slap together accounting integration
that just we kept tacking things on we kept working with the customers to improve it um that was selling really really well
uh and and so this has kind of been one of the things that we've um been battling this entire time is i i
was always traditionally wanted really quality software co-founder just really wanted to serve the customer well we've been butting heads and to the
point where we actually just built each other's systems separately so i built the api he built the accounting integration
and almost to this day we kind of still do that and it highlights one of the important
things i want to raise here is that um it's not a be all and end all
i think you need to pull back your software quality thing and talk to customers more and be quicker with customer feedback
the quality doesn't always have to be immaculate you can kind of work with them but the key thing here is that i think
you should really be working with customers as soon as you can as early on as you
can because beautiful beautifully designed software that just isn't used isn't worth anything
um and we still kind of battle on this today um so it's an ongoing struggle sometimes we
do more quality sometimes we just rush more things but the key thing that i kind of took away from this and it it really reminded
me of when i way back when i worked at that payments company initially um which was
you know i looked around and the software was really crappy at that payments company at the beginning and i always wondered why they made so
much money and i realize now that the answer is that products don't compete companies do
and you can have a beautiful product that is clearly better than your competitors but if you can't sell that product well
then again it's not really worth more than your competitors and this is kind of at the same time
why i realized back at that original payments company that 50 of the business was sales people
and the other 50 percent was everyone else i t hr finance yada yada they had such a
well-oiled sales and marketing machine that that's how they dominated the market it didn't matter
how good the other products were they were always going to outsell you
and so to kind of sum up a couple of the key things there it's just like um
you can use surveys to ask for opinions and find some early customers that way um always be working with your customers
receiving feedback as you're building software and always be selling right um you can
be working with customers and building exactly what they want but if you say it's free it's free it's free it's free oh wait now it's ten thousand
dollars um this is just not gonna work you need to make sure that they're willing to pay for it at the same time
and kind of off the back of this as well as a second piece of advice for for building software um especially in
startup mode is don't be afraid to make mistakes we have made so many mistakes it's crazy
everything from like duplicate payments that's an easy
one um sometimes there was a seven duplicate payment so it's the same payment done seven times on the same day
um there was one where uh the fees for a payment kept getting added on top and on top and on top and on top
to the point where many months later the person was paying nearly 10 times what they were supposed to be paying
and in all of these cases people got upset at the time but there was an amazing amount of
forgiveness that i'd never saw coming and i think you know we were really
embarrassed but if you just talk to your customer um sort the problem out i think most people
just want their problem gone they don't care too much that something went wrong they just want things fixed
but if you support them you talk to them you build that relationship and you you you know just generally be positive the
amount of forgiveness that comes you know comes from customers using is incredible i thought we
we sank our company like four times already with some of the mistakes we've made um but people are surprisingly resilient
and as long as you can fix things and and be positive and pleasant um it's really not
uh it's not been a big deal it's certainly not as big a deal as i thought all of these problems would have been
and i think one of the takeaways i also take took from this is that people really remember how
you make them feel rather than specifics about you so they may not remember an email they may not remember a product or
a feature uh they may not remember even your name but if they probably will remember oh i had
a really good time with that person last time i met them or oh the software was pretty it was pretty cool like i

how you make them feel um and it's not just you know how your customers feel
